title: Testsheet for Opentype character sets (Western, Central Eurpoean)
content:
Hello,

I’m looking for an opentype testsheet (indesign or worddoc?) with which I can check a font I’m working on in various language settings and which shows the exotic characters (foreign languages, Math Characters etc) in real context. Probably as everyone else, I’m having a hard time designing and spacing characters which I don’t know their exact use.  
Is there something like this available?

Thanks in advance!

( I posted the same thing in “Design”. Wasn’t sure where it’s best to ask)

 [Continuum with Baltic glyphs, what about cyrillic? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016080352/http:/typophile.com/node/37841 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Brown Fox

comments.content: This is good stuff, thanks! I can’t wait to have Ebens compiled list. I wonder if something similar exists for Math characters?

Nick’s link is good, but some languages’ text is presented as an image (e.g. [Bengali](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016080352/http:/www.unhchr.ch/udhr/lang/bng.htm)). Luckily, the [UDHR in Unicode](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016080352/http:/typophile.com/wiki/UDHR%252Bin%252BUnicode) project is fixing that. Here’s the link:

[http://www.unicode.org/udhr/](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016080352/http:/www.unicode.org/udhr/ "http://www.unicode.org/udhr/")
I’ve also noticed that some of the Cyrillic texts at the UN cheat—i.e. they have some Latin letters (A, Y, P etc.) mixed in with the Cyrillic characters.
The list is almost done. The language Lingala is giving me a little bit of trouble.

Ah! Finally. It’s up and ready to download.

[http://typophile.com/node/31399](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016080352/http:/typophile.com/node/31399 "http://typophile.com/node/31399")
